If our sun [for example] exploded now it would take 8 minutes for us on Earth to see the explosion because it takes 8 minutes for the light to reach us from that distance. When we see the explosion of the sun we have a microsecond [& then we are vaporized] to realise it really happened 8 minutes before now.The event described in this article happened 27,000 years ago We are 26,000 light years away from the eventOur ancestors 1,000 years ago would have seen the initial explosion if it was bright enough What we see now in our instruments is the after effect of the explosion where the material has spread out into a bubble

[Wikipedia] Life takes a licking, but keeps on ticking.Speaking of deadly astronomical events, this reminded me of yesterday's release on the putative find of the world's third largest impact zone. "An asteroid measuring up to 20km across hit South Australia up to 360 million years ago and left behind the one of the largest asteroid impact zones on Earth, according to new research published today." ""It's likely to be part of a particular cluster that was linked with a mass extinction event at that time."" [  m  m  ]If it happened up to ~ 360 million years ago, that could be the Hangenberg event in the Late Devonian extinction series of events. [  m  m  ] Like the K-Pg impactor event, and "Unlike the [initiating] Kellwasser event, the Hangenberg event affected marine and terrestrial habitats."That would make it the 2nd impactor that could be tied to mass extinctions, unless I am mistaken. "Since clouds reflect sunlight back into space, more of them should mean a cooler climate (although that depends in part on the clouds' altitude)."This blanket statement needs a further qualification - it also depends on the time of day: cloud cover at night has the opposite effect of increasing surface air temperatures as it acts as an insulating barrier, preventing radiation of heat back out into space. I'm not sure about serrated knives causing less damage than a single blade. If the blade is sufficiently sharp there is already sufficient stress concentration to cut without damage. Surgeon's scalpels are, for the most part, straight edges and very, very, very sharp. So sharp that the natural tension of skin tends to pull the flesh away from the cut in almost an explosive manner.Serrated edges are great when you're cutting into something that yields as you try to cut or something that's not taut - like bread. The compression of the substrate will pack onto one of the tips of the serrated edge where the stress concentration can do its work.I suspect the reason the quills work better is that they're entering normally to the flesh (nominally) so it's the squishy-substrate problem. The flesh wants to move away from the compression.

As a point, serrated knives cut most foods less cleanly than a plain edge, all else equal.  A serrated knife works as a saw, leaving a relatively ragged cut compared to a well-maintained plain-edged knife.  There are, of course, exceptions; bread knives, for instance.A close analogy would be the pits in e.g. santoku; they reduce the resistance of the blade by allowing air to get between the matter being cut and the side of the blade.Regarding the use for patches and needles, I shouldn't wonder if there's a biodegradable material that could be used.  The needle is pushed through the skin and is left to break down. From what I have been able to read about this case (a lot), Mr. Bowman bought undifferentiated soybeans from the local grain elevator and planted them. Knowing or suspecting that most of them were likely GMO progeny (Roundup Ready), he sprayed them with Roundup and harvested them. Some of the harvested seed was used to plant subsequent crops.Scotus is going to struggle to split this baby. As Justice Scalia observed, ruling that the first generation progeny in the grain elevator is protected by patent will create a fair use problem that essentially gives the patent holder (Monsanto, in this case, but that's irrelevant) a legal claim over the use of what has historically been a commodity just because some of their patented technology might be present in some amount. The potential future ramifications are immense. Suppose a patent holder decides that since their GMO is loose in the general population (be it soybeans, salmon, flowers, sheep, or whatever), they are entitled to patent royalties on every sale of instances of that species because their patented genetic material is or might be present in some amount? The mind boggles.I think there is hope that Scotus will rule the first generation progeny as unprotected. Monsanto can reasonably foresee that the progeny of their seeds will be distributed as part of the general population of that commodity and be used as a commodity and that part of the reasonable use of that commodity is that they might be planted.The second generation progeny that Mr. Bowman used are another question entirely.I would guess that the second generation progeny harvested from the first generation progeny will be ruled as protected due to one unique aspect of this particular case. Mr. Bowman's application of Roundup to his planted crop of "undifferentiated" seeds ensured that the only plants that survived would be the ones carrying the protected Roundup Ready (RR) gene. In effect, the selection process triggered by the application of Roundup caused a new instance of protected GMO to be produced.I'm hoping that the first generation progeny is covered by exhaustion, because any other ruling will create a level of patent protection that will affect us in ways we can only guess at right now.

I am glad to finally see attempts to verify predictions. To me that is far more convincing than previous approaches which mainly try to fit past data.One thing I've come to realize is that science is an application of Bayesian inference (which is itself an extension of logic, see  E.T. Jaynes on probability theory). Namely, from two claims "if the theory is true, then we should observe the following", and "the following has indeed been observed", we draw an inference: "the theory is more plausible".The question is how much does an observation matter. How much do we adjust our evaluation of plausibility (posterior vs. prior probability of the theory)?Qualitatively, in order to get a stronger inference, you want a surprising prediction and a closely matching observation. Those characteristics were the beauty of some famously historical experiments. For me, climate science is having difficulties finding such critical predictions. In particular, average temperature predictions with a wide error range don't seem very surprising. The trouble is that I don't know how to quantify the surprise (how likely would the observation be if the theory was wrong?), so I rely on a gut feeling, which is clearly susceptible to bias and which cannot be rigorous.Anyways, that is just my perspective. I'm suggesting that to be more convincing, climate researchers need more observations matching specific predictions and they need to explain why those predictions are surprising.

The name is likely derived from the wave propagation mechanism known as 'scattering'.Basically, when a radio wave impinges on a perfectly smooth surface, you get a 'reflected' component and a 'transmitted' component, the relative strength of each being determined by the conductivity properties of the material.  This is analogous to the ray optics that you study in high school physics (angle of incidence = angle of reflection for the reflected component, etc.).  A smooth surface fabricated out of a perfect conductor should reflect 100% of the incoming signal power and transmit 0% of it.  This is why you would get no cell signal inside of a well constructed metallic box (the incoming signal cannot penetrate it) but you CAN get a decent signal inside of buildings with wooden or concrete walls (transmitted component is weak but detectable).So, what happens when the reflecting surface is not smooth, as in the case of a rough sea?  This leads to 'scattering' rather than 'specular reflection', wherein the reflected energy is scattered in many different directions, resulting in a much weaker signal being returned back to the satellite compared to the case of smooth sea.

It may be helpful to point out that the prime numbers used in RSA keys are very small compared to the Mersenne prime discovered, 4096 bit RSA keys use approximately 616 digit prime numbers, while the discovered Mersenne prime has over 17 million digits.

One misconception that this article implies is that we use prime numbers in public key cryptography.  In reality we use probabilistic algorithms to numbers that are very likely to be prime.  We call these "pseudoprimes" because we don't really know if they are prime or not (Note: this is a little bit of a misnomer because an actual pseudoprime is a number that passes a primality test, but isn't actually prime.  However, it is common usage to call these "pseudoprimes").  We can get as close as we like to confidence that a number is prime, it just requires more calculation.

I highly recommend the NumberPhile channel on youtube, they just had a video on perfect numbers, Mersenne Primes, and this newly discovered prime. Their videos aren't overly technical, and it's cool to see people who are so enthusiastic about math and science.

And indeed that's something that the search for large Mersenne numbers has encouraged; without having the big primes as a goal, I suspect the discrete-weighted-transform would not have been developed, and I suspect Woltman would not have written the series of superbly optimised fast Fourier transforms (about twice the speed of FFTW!) which Prime95 uses.This means that extremely sharp and convenient tools are available if anyone wants to do recreational mathematics with big (millions of digit) numbers nearly all of whose digits in some base are the same, and a lot of them can be used for big numbers in general.There are surprisingly many cases where efficient multiplication of million- to billion-digit numbers comes in useful; recently, it was the essential tool behind all the papers on how consumer devices were using inadequate entropy sources and generating easily breakable RSA keys for SSL.It's another example of developing a general-purpose technology which you aimed at a particular problem and the rest of the world can aim at their own.

The point is not only that finding marsenne primes has no practical application, but that it has no theoretical benefit either. In other words, there is no number theorist out there saying, "finally, they have found 2^123456... -1, I can finally prove my theory." True, Prime95 is one way to stress test a  cpu. Running it for thousands of hours on thousands of machines is still a waste of electricity. True, RSA encryption needs large primes, but they do not need to be that large, or marsenne. If the time ever comes when we need specific marsenne primes, we can search for them using future, better CPUs.   I'll say it again, if you want to donate spare cycles, you can help cure Alzheimer's at folding@home.

You missed the point of the article; the machine heats only portions of the wafers, leaving nearby areas cool, thus putting them under internal stress in order to cause non-visible cracks to fracture.

The intent it to detect likely to fail wafers before they make into the normal manufacturing process; these later process steps are the expensive ones in terms of chemicals, metals, time, energy, etc.Additionally this "detector" intentionally uses highly asymmetric heating to stress wafers so that bad ones break. This asymmetric heating should be far more energy efficient then later heating steps seen in typical furnaces. Also later heating steps in the process are design to be highly symmetric so they would not trigger similar failures.

Also, the notion that a heat-generating machine is efficient seems highly dubious. Are they saying that nearly 100% of the input energy is transferred to the wafer as heat?Also, as others have noted, $60,000-100,000 is cheap for industrial mass production equipment, and this particular machine may well have very high throughput. I did not realize that sorting polycrystalline silicon wafers for structural defects was such a problem in the PV industry. This machine will probably quickly become as standard as furnaces. The asymmetrical heating probably limits its use to pre-doped wafers as the uneven heating will also cause uneven diffusion of the dopants (maybe not too great an effect at 500 degrees C). If wafer breakage if primarily due to structural defects present in pre-processed wafers, this could be a huge help.

An assumption appears to be that the environment for DNA mutation would be the same in the mitochondria and in the nucleus, and so we could use the nuclear rate to read the mitochondrial clock.  I don't think that is valid.  First, the interior of the mitochondria is a strongly oxidizing environment, full of free oxygen radicals generated by the oxidative phosphorylation chain.  This would lead to more DNA mutations and so a different rate than the nuclear clock.Secondly, the mitochondrial DNA is wrapped up in different proteosomes than the nuclear DNA.  I really don't know if this would make a big difference, but should be considered.Finally, I believe that most of the DNA in the nucleus is protected, wrapped up around its proteosomes, in a relatively condensed form.  Most of the mitochondrial reading frames are open and active, and so more at risk for mutations.  Again, a different clock than the nucleus.

You have a particle that interacted with the system and measured spin up for the system.For the rest of the universe, the spin of the system remains up and down, in superposition.Now - another particle interacts with the system.1.Will it always measure spin up for the system? If so, the system is in an illusion of superposition (regarding spin) for the rest of the universe (the system has a definite value for spin; it's just that the rest of the universe doesn't have enough information to figure out which value this is). It is an illusion of superposition because true superposition means the system has both values for spin at the same time (as Bell's inequalities prove).2.Can it measure spin down for the system, too? If so, the system is collapsed to spin up for someone AND collapsed to spin down for someone else (attention - this is NOT superposition where both values for spin coexist in the system FOR ALL OBSERVERS). Indeed, the 'collapsed to spin up for someone AND collapsed to spin down for someone else' is not a state systems can be in/are found in (even quantum mechanical systems). That's why von Neumann called this the measurement problem.

The Many Worlds Interpretation may solve the measurement problem, but it replaces this with a lot of other problems. Yes, see .  A single junction solar cell with an ideal semiconductor has a maximum theoretical efficiency of 34%; silicon is at 29%.  The main problem is that the sunlight that makes up that 1kW/m2 is at different wavelengths, but a single junction solar cell works ideally only at one particular wavelength: any photons with less energy won't give an electron enough energy to jump from the valence to the conduction band, and any energy that a photon has in excess of the threshold is wasted.  This can partly be overcome by multi-junction solar cells, which allow you to pick several threshold values (like stacking multiple solar cells on top of one another: if the band gap is too high for the photon to be absorbed, it will pass through to the next cell).  This could get you to 68% if you could build a cell with infinite layers, but triple junction is the current, practical maximum, and has a theoretical limit of 42%.  Also, I don't think multi-junction solar cells ever win the $/watt department: they're mostly aimed at satellites and such where conversion efficiency is important, regardless of cost.

There is lots of direct evidence that virtual particles exist.   You can detect the net effect of virtual particles, so they are not "invisible", but the issue is that the virtual particles cannot be detected in such a way as to confirm their individual identity.   For example, when an electron follows a curved path in an electric field, we know that it is the exchange of virtual photons that cause the curvature of the path.  But the curve looks smooth, meaning that you are seeing the net effect of a vast number of virtual particle interactions.   But they  must exist, because as far as is known, all forces are mediated by the exchange of virtual bosons.  Anytime ANYTHING accelerates because of a force (with the possible exception of gravity, since gravitons haven't yet been confirmed), it is virtual particles carrying the force.

Since we are placental mammals, I should think so. Convincing for what? That we share a common ancestor with those organisms? We certainly do. However that common ancestor would be an older one than the common ancestor of placental mammals. Think of it like this:Placental Mammals - animals that have bilateral symmetry, whose mouth forms second in early development, who have a notochord during development, who have backbones, who have jaws, who have lobe-limbs, who have 4 limbs, who produce milk for their offspring, who have internal gestation with a placenta.vs Marsupial Mammals - animals that have bilateral symmetry, whose mouth forms second in early development, who have a notochord during development, who have backbones, who have jaws, who have lobe-limbs, who have 4 limbs, who produce milk for their offspring, who have external gestation in a pouch.-----Notice how all except the last part are exactly the same? Well, the placentals will have a common ancestor for their specific group, and the marsupials will have a common ancestor of their specific group. However, if we go back in time a little further, we will find a common ancestor of both groups (and if we throw in the monotremes, a common ancestor of all mammals), which would correspond with milk producing. If we cut off one clause at a time, we reach an even older common ancestor for the more general group: tetrapods, lobe-finned fish, jawed fish, all fish, chordates, all deuterostomes, and finally all bilateria (the common ancestor which would finally unite us with the insects and other arthropods, as well as molluscs and other groups). So, while you may find such similarities as a one-way digestive system or having eyes more convincing, those similarities describe common ancestors for a broader group than the one focused on in this study: the placental mammals.

You set up a physical system that undergoes the same (mathematical) transformations as your target system, run it, and measure the result. There are many times in which doing so would be theoretically faster than a digital computer, because of the complexity of the math involved. But... the world is not full of analog computers, because the general purpose-ness of the general purpose computer wins out. But if they are general purpose, algorithmic computers, where is the theory of them that says they will be great at anything new? Good old fashioned digital computers rely basically on (a) formal logic and (b) arithmetic. That's the whole Turing point. Quantum computers are universal, so in principle can be used for any calculation you like. But, as baloroth points out, quantum computers will probably be used only for very specific problems (like the simulation of quantum system), at least at first. And don't knock quantum simulations: they will offer the possibility of actually calculating material properties, rather than the current trial-and-error method. This will be truly revolutionary, hence the excitement.Second, quantum computers are not some version of analog computers. The basic mechanism is completely different (quantum vs. classical mechanics). The reason analog computers don't exist is that they cannot be made fault tolerant, and quantum computers can. In fact, there is an analog version of a quantum computer using so-called continuous variables, which also does not have a fault tolerance theorem. So in my opinion it is entirely unhelpful to bring in analog computing to the discussion, because it is and always has been a non-starter due to bad noise properties, both in the classical and the quantum world.

I hate to say this, but this story is a little short on detail for Ars.  tl;dr - buy honey from an actual farm or it's usually crap.To mikiev, there are a couple ways of doing this but I'll take a guess and (try to) explain.  The carbon in the CO2 represents all of the carbon that was in the honey (or whatever substance you're testing).  So, you can measure the various isotopes of carbon in the CO2 (12-C, 13-C, 14-C) and see what the ratio is.  The sugar (and proteins, if present) in the honey will have different ratios of 12-C/13-C based on the plant source of the honey (the nectar harvested by the bees).  The ratio can tell you if the honey derived from a C3 plant or C4 plant.  Unfortunately, flowers (good) and rice (bad) are both C3 plants, so isotope ratios can't differentiate between them, usually.  Maybe this newer method can, but that detail isn't here.  Corn is C4, so honey adulterated with HFCS or something is easy to spot.  The Chinese know this and have mostly abandoned using HFCS and use rice syrup almost exclusively now.  As to why there are different ratios, it comes from enzymatic kinetic isotope effects.  At every step of the sugar synthesis in the plant, enzymes are involved.  For each reaction, catalysed by an enzyme, the exact chemical mechanism will favor either the lighter (12-C) or heavier (13-C) isotope of carbon.  In the end, each one of the carbons in the sugar will be at a pretty constant ratio (12/13) based on the different enzymes in the process.  Now, even though different plants will use the same enzyme to catalyse a particular reaction, they will differ just enough that the ratio of 12-C to 13-C will be just a little different.  In the end, the additive effect will be to give you different 12-C/13-C ratios in the final sugars.  This is measurable.  The isotope effect is much more pronounced with hydrogen (1-H/2-H), but it's much harder to measure, so it's usually not done.  It's a technical nightmare to measure these tiny differences in the intact molecule, so we burn the sugar into CO2 and measure it there. The evolutionary trail is pretty sparse, and understandably so.  To really piece together the evolutionary story, you'd need to have the genomes of all the ancestors dating back 50 million years or so and then map out the specific changes that occurred in the genome. But, that would only tell a small portion of the story because science can't look at a genome and tell you how and when genes are expressed, and what they would actually do.  For example, with respect to the bat. science doesn't know what echo location looks like at the genomic level, nor can it point to the region of the genome that builds machines that can repair damaged DNA.  Its a bit like looking at the byte codes of a compiled program, and trying to figure out what the program does without knowing the underlying machine that interprets the byte codes or the common libraries and hardware that the program runs on.  Speculating that the genome of the bat is smaller due to selective pressure due to the energy demands of copying is counter-productive and ascribes to evolution more than is actually known.

I always wonder when this kind of post appears if the poster is a scientist afraid of readers misled by a rhetorical shorthand common to communication in the sciences, or an enthusiastic layperson ready to step in to correct what is, again, just a rhetorical shorthand. Even on its face, that statement from the article isn't nearly as egregious as saying something like "evolution designed the brain to not simply self-allocate...", which would still be skipped over in most circles, since the primary audience for this research would be unlikely to assume you were in the intelligent design camp. Hence the concerned citizen that steps in to correct reporting to the secondary, popular audience who might get the wrong idea from that sort of statement.Regardless, I agree that we need to be careful with how we communicate science, but I also agree with bsharp (and wyrmhole) that you're being overzealous in this case. I would go even further than bsharp by saying that the statement isn't just fine for a popular audience, it's a fine summary for anyone. The statement *does not* imply a higher order intelligence, just the presence of a higher order regulation system. Both of the feedback mechanisms you describe would fall under that description, and, considering the results of this study, we can at least guess that this feedback mechanism is being actively selected for; it's not just an emergent phenomenon under no selective pressure. I'd personally be fine with going further and saying that the brain was therefore *designed* to deal with starvation in this manner, but that's because I'm ok with the idea of design without a designer. Just like you appear to be ok with a mechanism being tuned without a tuner Anyway, saying that the brain is doing these things is merely synecdoche, with no implication of the involvement of homunculi. Speculation on a mechanism of action is then just an interesting addendum, not a correction of excessive anthropomorphizing.

I understand your initial reaction, but Chris is right in this case. The reason not to use a classical computer with a quantum network is that it is the sending of a quantum entangled state that is important. With the possible exception of quantum encryption, there is no point in using a quantum network with a classical computerit buys you no capability. But for a quantum computer, being able to transmit a quantum state is a very big deal and allows you to do things you otherwise could not. Similarly, for quantum packets you cannot build a network from a series of classical point to point communications. Reading the routing header would destroy the quantum state you are interested in, and there is no way to build a repeater to boost the signal. Effectively what has been done here is to design a way to read a routing header and packet, even with data loss, and make a new boosted packet with the same entangled state and going in the right direction, all without performing the dreaded 'measurement' that would destroy the encoded quantum state.Another way to think about it is you need to build a network where you never actually detect an single photon, as that destroys the information you were trying to send. Tricky, and it sounds like this is a clever answer. Chris, a question for you. In this process have they given up quantum cryptography?  Lets say you build the packet to withstand a 75% photon loss. Can you put in a beamsplitter and read your 'copy' of the packet without affecting the state of the transmitted packet? If yes, then even for a packet that can sustain lower losses, could you potentially pick off small percentage of the beam before and after each router reboosts the signal, kind of a quantum non-destruct attack?

I guess it would be more correct to say start-point to destination-point. Although the article doesn't say it explicitly, single photon states are destroyed by intermediate nodes, so, no, I am not missing the point at all.That is a good point. I would guess that you still have some encryption capability because you have to scale the size of the error correction block with loss, so, doubling the loss would be noticed in increased channel loss. If you reduce the beam-splitting ratio so that the loss becomes smaller, then you retrieve less of the information, so, I guess it is less secure than single photon qubits, but is still more secure than classical communication.

At such low light levels, we do not "perceive" brightness linearly.  Have you ever realized that Mars changes in brightness by almost a factor of 100 throughout the year? There have been solar storms that produced fantastic aurora displays, but the auroral ring remained around or above the arctic circle, so were not seen at lower latitudes like in the U.S.  Such displays would go completely unnoticed during the summer when those high latitudes have 24 hours of daylight/twilight.This is not to say that a giant solar storm, producing 20 times the protons as the largest storm on record, absolutely could escape detection. I can't speak about all crypto, but interestingly, another class of primes called Sophie Germain primes play a role in cryptography. A prime p is Sophie Germain iff 2p+1 is prime. 2p+1 is then called a "safe prime". Like Mersenne primes, we also don't know whether there are infinitely many Sophie Germain primes.Safe primes have applications in crypto. For example, see the 's section on pseudorandom number generators. Another application is in El Gamal encryption, which involves computations in a group. We choose this group to be the quadratic residues mod p for a safe prime p. Another is the simple collision-resistant hash function f(x, y) = g^xh^y for fixed generators g and h of the quadratic residues mod safe prime p.As an aside, there is an indirect application of Mersenne primes to crypto. As I mentioned earlier in this thread, the family of locally decodable codes (LDCs) called matching vector codes rely on Mersenne primes. LDCs provide private information retrieval (PIR) algorithms, which is a topic in crypto. You can read Yekhanin's thesis/mini-book on LDCs and PIR if you want.

Interesting article and some good points you raise. It should be pointed out that while the California Public Health Goal is 0.02 ug/L, the Maximum Contaminant Limit is 50 ug/L (although this is currently being revised; very curious what they end up on, as naturally-occurring Cr6+ is quite widespread in the area where I live; anything below about 30 ug/L is going to have massive cost impacts to a lot of communities). A few more issues. The article mentions that the narrator or presenter of the show filters his water because hex chrome was detected at 0.19 ug/L. If he is using a normal carbon filter, it really doesn't work very well for hex chrome. The chrome will bind to the activated carbon loosely for a while, but it is dislodged very easily by other common contaminants. Running water with elevated hex chrome through a filter can actually result in pulses of water in the effluent enriched with hex chrome compared to the influent concentration. A reverse-osmosis filter should be effective, though. Another issue to point out is that anthropogenic hex chrome is often not the result of dumping chromium (or hex chrome), but rather changes to the geochemistry of the aquifer (through releases of other chemicals) that results in oxidation of naturally occurring trivalent chromium to hexavalent chromium. Of course, this tends to happen in areas with elevated chromium to begin with, so it is often very difficult to determine whether elevated hex chrome is naturally occurring or the result of anthropogenic activity. In some areas the biggest source of anthropogenic hex chrome contamination is actually the result of earlier cleanups of other contaminants, especially chlorinated VOCs (one of the preferred methods for cleaning up PCE, for example, is to inject a chemical oxidant to break down the PCE; in the wrong soil type, you end up with a nice Cr6+ plume, which can be much harder to address than the original solvent plume). I hadn't even heard about this PBS show on the subject, but it is a really interesting issue. Especially for Californians, as our location on the edge of a tectonic plate means we have lots of altered ultramafics (such as serpentine) that are enriched in heavy metals such as chromium. I assume Oregon and Washington have similar issues, but they are likely less dependent on groundwater than places like the Central Valley.

I'm a bit confused by this statement from the article - while technically this is correct (due to perspective, objects closer to the observer appear larger than objects further away) in this case the observer (Kepler) is essentially so massively far away from the star+planet system that there would be no observable size difference between a planet transiting 10 million miles away from its star and a planet 100 million miles away.There would obviously be a timing difference (the planet further away will take longer to transit), but the occulting disk would essentially be the same size in both cases, so the dip in brightness will also be the same.

Kepler is designed to detect brightness variations regardless of cause (would be difficult to do otherwise anyway) - so yes, changing phases and illuminated when they are moving behind their star would be detectable - in fact this effect has been seen for a long time in cases of close binary stars where one of the stars is much brighter than the other.However, the same argument applies : we are talking about variations orders of magnitude smaller than the eclipses themselves, so you'd only be able to detect them on very big planets very close to their parent star, and only planets which reflect a lot of the infalling light (our moon, for example, absorbs 90% of infalling light and is actually very dark - the "albedo" of the moon is 0.11).So the size of this effect is not just influenced by the planet's distance from the star and its diameter but also by its albedo value.

What is meant is that assuming 2 planets of the same diameter, one being closer to the star than the other, the closer one blots out more of the star's visible "disk". Its orbit being closer in will likely be much smaller and will indicate a much faster revolution around the star it orbits.  Its transit across the disk of the star will be much quicker than the same sized plant further out from the star.

Considering the distances involved to begin with, and the minuteness of light variations detected by Kepler, it's not hard to believe orbital distance could have a measurable impact (from Kepler's point of view) on the light blocked by the planet.What I don't understand is why objects with a smaller orbit would have a larger eclipse, all else being equal.  Given two planets of equal size and equal star brightness, wouldn't the one closer to Kepler (the one with the larger orbit, not smaller orbit) have a larger apparent eclipse?  The quote you linked above from the article seems to indicate the inverse is true.That's like saying holding a pencil 6 inches in front of your eye and blocking the TV screen will let more light in to your eye than taping the pencil directly to the TV screen.  This does not make sense to me.

Heat from the semiconductor is transformed into radiation which is emitted into the room. This is really just a very sophisticated refrigerator. Heat is absorbed by "low" temperature atoms in the semiconductor, the laser acts like the compressor, pumping these atoms up to a "high" temperature where they can emit both the heat and absorbed laser energy into the room through emission. The difference between the energy of the absorbed and emitted photons is equal to the heat extracted from the semiconductor.Just like a refrigerator, the energy required to run the laser will also be added to the room as wasted heat.

I think again you can think of 'non-locality' as meaning this. All non-locality means is that 2 things somehow interact over a distance without any regard for what is between them. You could consider this to be a sort of 'extra dimension' in which these objects are close to each other.

Locality is simply an observed property of the physical macroscopic universe. The relationships between objects are largely determined by the physical distances between them. Newton simply stated that it would be irrational because EVERYTHING he could see around him supported the notion that locality was absolute. He was simply being rational. In terms of Relativity it isn't so much that it is built AROUND locality as that locality is axiomatic in any theory of space and time. Space (at least) is ALL ABOUT locality. The limitations on velocity are simply a consequence of the way relativity is structured. They arise out of the nature of the underlying space and time. It isn't a priori necessary that information can't travel faster than light (and in some solutions of GR this does happen), just that if you have such things happening then you lose causality and conservation laws, and effectively lose locality as well. Ultimately you have theory of nothing at that point.The thing is, none of this really talks to whatever 'deeper reality' there would be in say a holographic universe, one where other universal variables exist that mediate interactions which are non-local. Again, since GR/SR don't forbid the passing of information at faster than light these things aren't incompatible, they just force you to give up notions like absolute causality and absolute global conservation laws (they actually do exist, but not in the sense we normally think of).

One of the authors' claims is just plain wrong - they say that "infection with viral vectors requires several days for the transgene to be expressed." The off-the shelf lentivirus or adenovirus vectors require several days for expression to reach a peak/plateau, but good expression can certainly be achieved within 24 hours. I like the authors' work, and they achieve nice expression but this is very much a tool for studying early life mouse brains. Plasmid electroporation in developing mouse brains has been pioneered by several Japanese researchers ( m  m ). The mode of delivery means that the area of expression is small - a few mm sq. Delivery is limited by the diffusion of the plasmid which is aided by what is, essentially, in vivo electrophoresis. Not really so good if we want to genetically engineer a voluminous adult human brain. Even with viral vectors for treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, delivery over large areas is still tough, requiring multiple burr holes, and delivery at several brain depths (Ron Crystal's lab) or taking advantage of the innate massive interconnectedness of the brain (Krystof Bankiewicz's lab) to inject in one region to achieve delivery to another, remote area.

The individual photons don't curve.  The holographic filter merely produces a region of high intensity that follows a curved path.  Think back to the old double slit experiment.  It produces an interference pattern, with oscillating regions of high and low intensity.  This is the same exact thing, but instead of a pair of slits, the holographic filter is specially designed to produce a curve.  You are emitting photons/electrons that are filling the entire area, but constructive and destructive interference means they only manifest themselves along that curve.  It's "self healing" not because the beam somehow travels through the object, but because the lightfield recreates the beam on the opposite side, when it is no longer shadowed by the object. "In the traditional way of thinking, the particle and wave natures of photons cannot be accessed simultaneously. "IDK why anyone would just assume this. Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle only referred to position and momentum because they are equivalent under entirely generic conditions by a Fourier Transform. In a generalization of this, it turns out that any two operators that are conjugates in a finite dimensional Hilbert space e.g. charge and phase will obey a similar uncertainty. The so-called duality has very little to do with the "nature" of light and matter at the atomic scale, and everything to do with attempts to naively impose a classical description of the phenomena on the quantum reality.

"In the traditional way of thinking, the particle and wave natures of photons cannot be accessed simultaneously."This is the legacy of the Copenhagen interpretation. It has already been disproved. A double-slit experiment has been done where the time it took a single photon to reach the detectors was measured. It was determined that only two amounts of time could be measured, the amount of time it would take the quantum to past through one or the other slit (50-50 chance). Thus, the particle nature of the quantum (which path it took) and the wave nature (the interference pattern) was measured at the same time.Quanta are both waves and particles at the same time. They only appear as one or the other because experimenters ignore the other property.

A solar cell must allow low-energy photons to escape rather than produce heat or disrupt higher-energy photons reacting with the substrate. I'd say if you think about it this almost has to be the case. Closely related species often behave in similar ways. Clearly if a large amount of difference in genetics were required in order to control this then it would be rather unlikely that A) complex behaviors would ever evolve at all or that B) they would prove to be so easily modified or elaborated. One might well posit that taxa which evolve in the direction of 'evolvability' (which would include high level behavior and structure mediated by a few key genes) acquire greater fitness over geologic time. Imagine a 'mouse' in which every detail of the burrowing behavior is controlled by many genes which don't work under the control of a few moderators. Such mice would only function properly if all these genes worked correctly (compatibly at least) and it would be unlikely that such behavior could evolve in a coherent fashion. When compared to the actual mouse we see in reality this mouse would fair poorly over evolutionary time.

The authors say that most similar studies have looked at behaviors that will only take place in lab environments, and that this is one of the first to take a look at a behavior that's a clear replication of something that takes place in the wild and has been under natural selection.There are many studies that perform similar work with morphology: the shape and location of body parts.

There's plenty of precedent for complex behaviours having a simple trigger; the parasite that makes an ant cling to the top of a blade of grass so that it can be eaten by a cow, and so go on to the next stage of its life-cycle, or another parasite that causes mice to hunt out the smell of cats rather than avoid it, for similar reasons, or Langton's  Ant, where we actually know everything about the system but have no idea what's going on. Or any hormone or neurotransmitter, I suppose. These are just examples that occurred to me off the top of my head while I was reading the article.Neat finding, though.

That's what this study is trying to do.Incidentally, this should sound warning bells for anyone considering modifying genes in humans to "improve" humanity - behavioural changes resulting from such a thing could potentially eliminate what makes us "human."(edited to add the following)What makes you so sure that it's an either/or proposition? What if it's a bi-directional process, whereby behaviours influence genes and genes influence behaviours? This would explain why genetic mutation occurs throughout populations - an individual tries a certain behaviour, if they perceive the result as successful they do more of it and it follows a path of, e.g. initial attempt -> conscious habit -> unconscious habit -> semi-autonomous response ("muscle memory") -> genetic trait. This would help explain the anomaly between the estimated number of random mutations that would have been needed for life as we know it to have developed on Earth and the average time between them given our current estimates of when life began: THE MUTATIONS ARE NOT RANDOM. Certain behaviours are much more likely given existing genetic traits, those behaviours lead to modified genetics which then influence the next generation(s). Edge cases of unlikely behaviours still occur; if the success of these is comparatively  much, much better than the general population then it leads the evolution in a different direction - more successful for the species/genus concerned.

I believe that pathogens are subject to evolutionary pressures that limit their virulence.  If a pathogen ever evolves that is so successfully deadly that it kills its hosts instantly, it will probably kill everyone in range of infection and then promptly go extinct, or at least dormant.  Since most pathogens rely in some fashion on their hosts' biochemistry for optimal reproductive success, the most widespread and evolutionarily successful pathogens are the ones that are either non-lethal or at least that spread much faster than they kill.It's unlikely that a universally-lethal highly-infectious pathogen would arise at any given time, because the overall evolutionary pressure on diseases is actually away from being lethal.  Less infectious lethal pathogens kill their vectors and don't reach the full vulnerable population.  It can happen, which is why we've had pandemics in human history.Lastly, just disabling the immune system isn't a free pass.  After all, most plants and simpler organisms don't have anything like the human immune system, but they still find enough ways to resist or avoid disease enough to get by.  Something tells me that many of the factors that apply in those cases also work in our favor, above and beyond the benefits we get from our immune systems and from being smart enough to fight back on time scales of years rather than generations.

Thanks for the article, it's a very interesting subject.With any test for disease, it's trivially easy to be very good at identifying it when it's there (sensitivity) - you just set your threshold for calling disease very low. Obviously, the downside is you generate a ton of false positives. Alternatively, you can go the other way and make your test really good at avoiding false positives (specificity) by setting your threshold for calling disease very high but that comes at a cost of missing disease.A quick glance at Table 2 (after a moment of gratitude for the fact that it's open access) suggests that's pretty much how these apps work. All have either very high sensitivity but poor specificity or vice versa. If I were a developer, depending on how cynical I was feeling and the legal risks involved, I'd consider setting my threshold very high to minimise the number of false positives. The way these apps are likely to be used in the general population, the vast majority of suspicious lesions that people test them on are likely to be benign so on a per-user basis, you'd probably be 'right' the large majority of the time if you just called everything benign. With the money saved by not working on a real algorithm, I'd pay for a lawyer to defend me against the very small number of people suing because my app gave them a false negative and false reassurance. A bit of market and epidemiological research and I'd probably have quite a decent business model.In fact, App 3, looks suspiciously like it's doing exactly that with 7% sensitivity and ~93% specificity.

I wanted to add that these apps use the traditional ABCD rules for detecting suspicious lesions; A for asymmetry, B for irregular borders, C for color variation, and D for diameter larger than 6mm. Many melanomas display one or more of these clinical signs and these rules have saved lives thanks to making them known to health care workers and the public alike. One problem: the most dangerous type of melanoma (nodular melanoma) frequently displays NONE of the ABCD signs these apps use. Not only will nodular melanoma be missed by people using ABCD rules, but these phone apps can give a false sense of security that can directly lead to the death of the user. Unlike the three other types of melanoma, nodular melanoma has an early vertical growth phase and will not be large in diameter or irregular. Worst yet, melanomas in their vertical growth phase are invading the dermis and gaining metastatic potential. Remember that with melanoma, traditional chemotherapy and radiation are not effective and once the disease spreads beyond its primary site, the 5 year survival rates are some of the worst of any cancer. The only way we know of to effectively treat melanoma is to excise it with wide margins while it is still confined at the original lesion. These apps and the false sense of security they lend may eliminate the motivation for people with nodular melanoma to seek the only therapy known to be efficacious in curing the disease. If you have a pigmented lesion that is new, changing, or markedly different from other moles on your skin, see a dermatologist immediately. It is literally impossible to overstate the importance of catching melanoma early.

So all of physics breaks down.[This is not my argument, but Aaronson's. He has written a paper reviewing all of this.] Church-Turing vs physics is analogous to relativity vs physics - without it, no physics predicting observations. This is because computing devices are physical and that is why computer science concerns itself with resources of time and space (number of gates).

Church-Turing just says that any computer can simulate any other, given infinite resources, and says nothing about how quickly a given computer can solve a problem versus another.  So yes, a standard computer with infinite memory can simulate a quantum computer, very slowly, and solve the same problems, at not necessarily the same speed.  Or you can just build a quantum computer and skip the infinite memory step and experience a massive speedup in some problems.  Analogously, it is true that there exists a DFA capable of simulating any NFA, but the DFA will in general have exponentially more states than the NFA (the DFA's states are in general the powerset of the NFA's states).  Sure, in principle some DFA can do any calculation any NFA can do, but the NFA is way better at doing it.

I don't know what kind of neural network they're using, but don't forget about self-organizing networks (). Those kinds of networks don't require any training examples, they will naturally highlight the areas with the least differences - the network will believe that such "islands of relative homogeneity" are classes of things, because they're similar. To be clear: self-organizing maps do require training, but you don't have to train it with examples. You just feed it the data, and after a while it will begin to see classes of data - all by itself!

Special and general relativity take mass for granted; higher speed means higher kinetic energy and some people (mistakenly) translate that via E = mc^2 to a higher mass.The Higgs mechanism explains where mass comes from at low velocities (interestingly also via E = mc^2, but now via the potential energy of the interaction between the particle that is to acquire mass and the Higgs particles).

The Higgs field explains how a particle just sitting there, with no apparent interactions, can have an energy associated with it.  We equate this "rest energy" with a particle's mass.  The apparent increase in mass a particle experiences at nonzero speeds is actually just the particle's kinetic energy, not really a change in its mass.So, E=mc^2 is actually saying that a particle carries around with it some inertia constant, m, that results from a potential with respect to the Higgs field E, divided by the c^2 unit conversion factor.  Potentials with respect to other forces add energy and hence "mass" too.  The Higgs is special only in that its vacuum expectation value is nonzero (ie, there's not some constant background electric field throughout all space causing all electrically charged particles to carry around some minimum amount of potential energy, but there is some constant background Higgs field).
"developed a theoretical model that explained the masses of all known particles through an interaction with a field"Neutrinos.

Faster moving particles do in fact create stronger gravitational fields.  A hot sun has stronger gravity than a cold sun (of exactly the same composition) because its energy density is larger.  Still, the word mass is *normally* taken as the rest frame constant (so the term "mass" implies the 0) while the additional apparent mass at nonzero speeds is interpreted as kinetic energy, not a "mass" increase. m  m

The transistors in a computer are either on or off. Yes, we can operate with analog thresholds but the fundamental logic that invades computers is Boolean operations.That said, there's nothing that says the math inside the computer can't be used to represent base 10 rather than base 2. Long ago at the dawn of the computer age (and by dawn I believe it might have been around the time of Babbages machines) someone went to the effort of figuring out how many operations would be required to perform additions in base 10 vs. in base 2. It turns out that base 2 requires fewer operations than any other base. And since any base can be transformed into any other base quite trivially there's no penalty performance-wise. It was a long while until computers actually performed multiplies without adding numbers repetitively so for all I know it takes fewer operations to multiply in base 10 than in base 2. I certainly don't know the answer to that but someone else may. However, by that point we were committed to base 2 as the fundamental architecture of computers and that's not likely to change for a long, long, long time.

WinFS:In a networked world, how is it useful for an OS to structure document-related data in a proprietary way that is unsupported by other OSes?I have the same complaint when people rave about the meta-data support in BeOS.  You can manage your mp3 collection beautifully with all that meta-data.  But if that data cannot be manipulated in a standardized way along with the file (including the ability to transfer that data along with the file and have a recipient's system be able to make use of that data), then you don't have anything that is useful in a big-picture way.Imagine if EXIF data for images were stored at the FS-level.  Is that really more useful than having it part of the standard document format?  Right now, document-embedded EXIF data means that you don't need all possible OSes that would handle the file to have compatible meta-data layers in order for the data to be transferred to and usable on different systems.  If such data were stored in FS-level structures, every OS that touches the file would have to be meta-data-aware or the data wouldn't just be useless, it would be lost.  Remember, a photo starts on a camera device and may variously end up passing through Android, iOS, Windows, Linux with various FSes, Mac OS X, Google's proprietary FS, etc.And once you decide (like most users will) that you don't want to create your own custom system for tagging your mp3s, you will choose an app that will manage that process.  And then as a user you don't really care what the underlying process is for storing that data, except that you'd like many of the fields to transfer over if you send a file to a buddy.  Which is really an argument for embedding document-type-specific meta-data directly into the document format, rather than relying on OS meta-data support.

I think this explanation is wrong. At ground level, CO2 and water vapor make the atmosphere completely opaque to infrared. Any change doesn't make a difference. As you go up, however, due to the lower pressure, the atmosphere becomes steadily more transparent. At a certain point, the infrared can finally escape into space. Adding CO2 increases the height of this point. At this higher point, the temperature is lower, and lower temperature matter emits less radiation. It is this effect that changes the energy balance.See Edit: Apparently the full story is much more complex than this: see Still, I think the simplified explanation here allows deniers to make their saturation argument, which is unfortunate. The average-height-of-final-emission argument makes that much harder.

Also it should be noted that an 'LED' screen is simply an LCD screen that is backlit by LEDs. The white light generated by the LEDs passes through a polarising filter that absorbs around half the light. Reflective polarisers can let through more than 50% of the light as polarised light by reflecting and recycling the light that isn't of the selected polarisation.After the polarising filter, the light passes through a colour filter, which for each of the three colours will block at least two thirds of the light.Consequently, only about 20%, at most, of the generated light will make it out of the screen (when the screen is completely white). All of the light generated by an OLED is intended to be seen, so the efficiency depends only on the light generating efficiency and any transient absorption.

Entropy, roughly speaking, is a measure of disorder. It applies to very unphysical things like computer files (encrypted files have more entropy than plaintext files, because they are made to look more random) as well as physics. In general, things we consider 'hot' have more entropy (more random motion of particles). Also things which are broken into lots of little bits have more entropy (because they have less structure) than things which are whole. One of the laws of physics is you can't reduce the entropy in the universe. You can reduce the entropy in your little corner of the world but doing so take energy which ultimately increases entropy somewhere else. What you are talking about is one hypothetical end of the universe, where entropy is maximized, probably by a uniform cloud in all directions, but not by every atom being in the same state. Rather it would be like perfect static... noisy, but noisy everywhere in the universe, with no order anywhere in existence.

The phase information is of overwhelmingly greater importance than the amplitude information in the spatial frequency domain.There are a lot of comments so far that are (understandably) pointing to the lack of information present in an image as being the cause for its fundamental resolution limit. However, this turns out not to be the case. There was a beautiful paper published way back in the '60s that showed how objects of finite angular extent can be imaged with resolution far beyond the diffraction limit using the method of analytic reconstruction. There exists one nasty little caveat, however: the spectrum of the object must be known perfectly over an arbitrary segment. If a portion of the spectrum can be known perfectly, the entire spectrum of the object can be recovered perfectly and with infinite resolution. But to know a portion of a spectrum perfectly means to measure it without the presence of noise. It is therefore noise (right down to the photon-counting limit) that limits the resolution, not the capture resolution itself.LKeene w  w

I believe we are implying different cause and effect.  Systems do not collapse into disks because of cooling.  The same phenomena that drive collapse also drive cooling.  Friction and inelastic collisions both result in each particle's angular momentum approaching the average*.  And friction and inelastic collisions both also result in conversion of potential and kinetic energy to heat, which is then radiated away from the system.  But the collapse and the radiation are both effects.  Neither cause the other.*"Each particle's angular momentum approaching the average" is not actually a correct description of the end-point of the disk-making process, but I think people generally understand the shorthand when I say it that way.  Basically, what you really end up with is momentum transferred between objects (atoms, molecults, particles of dust, etc.) until each object ends up in a relatively circular orbit in the same eliptic as the other objects (such that further jostling and momentum transferring is limited).  Because objects have different masses and their velocities depend on distance from the center, it is not accurate to say that their momentums will be the same.

Orbital mechanics are somewhat non-intuitive. When a spacecraft fires it's retro-rockets, they cause it to drop into a lower orbit (or out of orbit). Regarding atovaquone resistance due to mutation of the Qo site within cyt b. bc1 has two quinone binding sites; Qo (quinol oxidation) and, on the opposite side of the membrane, Qi, the site of quinone reduction. Despite binding essentially the same substrate, the sites are structurally diverse, and often show selectivity for different classes of Q site inhibitors (compare the mode of action of myxothiazol with stigamatellin or atovaquone, say). Sometimes only very small structural differences are required to drive antagonist selectivity, and some compounds, such a quinolones, can bind to both sites with equal efficacy. Resistance-conferring mutation within Qo confers a fitness penalty on Plasmodium (the bc1 complex is less efficient), and so it seems unlikely that double Qo/Qi mutation would be tolerated by the organism. Research into Qo/Qi inhibitors is still very much an ongoing business.Atovaquone resistance paper plug:  m  m Plasmodium bc1 inhibitors:  m  m Nick Fisheredit: typo
